nodes.name: India
nodes.explanation: India's health indicators have lagged behind those of its peer nations.

nodes.name: Population
nodes.explanation: The country has a population of 1.3 billion.

nodes.name: Health Workers Density
nodes.explanation: India has a health workers density of doctors and nurses/midwives of 5.0 and 6.0 respectively, for 10,000 persons.

nodes.name: WHO Threshold
nodes.explanation: The WHO recommends a threshold of 44.5 doctors, nurses, and midwives per 10,000 population.

nodes.name: Health System Challenges
nodes.explanation: The issue is compounded by the skewed inter-state, urban-rural, and public-private sector divide.

nodes.name: Universal Health Coverage
nodes.explanation: Addressing the paucity of skilled personnel is crucial for achieving universal health coverage.

nodes.name: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
nodes.explanation: India aims to accelerate its progress toward achieving its SDGs.

nodes.name: Federal Health Budget
nodes.explanation: The recent increase in the federal health budget offers an opportunity to address healthcare challenges.

nodes.name: READ Approach
nodes.explanation: The READ approach is a systematic method for document analysis in health policy research.

nodes.name: Public Health Sector
nodes.explanation: Government-funded and provides healthcare to vulnerable populations.

nodes.name: Private Health Sector
nodes.explanation: Dominant provider of healthcare and perceived to offer quality care.

nodes.name: Ashas and ANMs
nodes.explanation: ASHAs are female community health workers supporting ANMs with expanded reach.

nodes.name: Rural Medical Assistants (RMAs)
nodes.explanation: RMAs work at Primary Health Centers and have a positive initial evaluation.

nodes.name: Ayushman Bharat
nodes.explanation: A publicly financed health insurance scheme for the poor in India.

nodes.name: National Medical Council (NMC)
nodes.explanation: Revamped to improve regulation of health professionals and medical education.

nodes.name: Digital Technology
nodes.explanation: Used to facilitate India's vaccination program and medical services.

nodes.name: Medical Tourism
nodes.explanation: India is a leading destination for medical tourism with world-class health facilities.

edges.content: India has an estimated active health workers density much lower than the WHO recommended thresholds.
The paucity of skilled personnel needs to be addressed if India is to achieve universal health coverage.
The density of health workers is related to India's population.
The health workers density in India is lower than the WHO threshold.
The issue is compounded by a skewed inter-state, urban-rural, and public-private sector divide.
The WHO threshold suggests adequate health workers density compared to India's current state.
Achieving universal health coverage is part of India's sustainable development goals.
Progress towards sustainable development goals includes achieving universal health coverage.
The recent increase in the federal health budget offers an unprecedented opportunity for India.
The READ approach helps analyze the implications of the federal health budget.
There is a growing divide between the public and private health sectors.
The private health sector has enabled India to become a leading destination for medical tourism.
ASHAs and Rural Medical Assistants (RMAs) are strategies to extend health service reach.
Ayushman Bharat involves private health facilities to provide secondary and tertiary care.
The National Medical Council remains silent on the relationship between the private sector and healthcare regulation.
Digital technology supports India's medical tourism industry through advanced services.
